error.signature: broken link from tree abc123 to blob def456

verdict.summary: git fsck reports broken links between objects, indicating missing or corrupted objects in the repository. Usually caused by disk corruption, interrupted gc operations, or shallow clone issues.

dead_ends.action: Running git gc --aggressive to fix the broken links
dead_ends.why_fails: gc cannot recreate missing objects; it may actually make things worse by removing dangling objects that could help with recovery

dead_ends.action: Ignoring the fsck warnings and continuing to use the repo
dead_ends.why_fails: Broken links can cascade during merge/rebase operations, leading to data loss when git tries to read the missing objects

workarounds.action: Fetch missing objects from the remote
workarounds.how: Run git fetch --all to retrieve objects from all remotes. Then run git fsck again to verify. Missing objects from the remote fill in the broken links.

workarounds.action: Re-clone the repository if corruption is extensive
workarounds.how: Backup any local-only branches by creating patches (git format-patch), then re-clone. Apply patches to the fresh clone to recover local work.

leads_to.condition: when broken links indicate deeper object corruption
when the broken link is in the commit chain leading to HEAD

preceded_by.condition: when interrupted gc leaves the repository with missing objects
when individual object corruption leads to broken references

frequently_confused_with.distinction: broken-link means a referenced object is missing; object-corrupted means an object exists but its contents are invalid or cannot be parsed
